Jinnō Shōtōki. p. 239. ==Events of the Kengen era== * 1302 (Kengen 1): The central structure of Shin-Yakushi-ji Buddhist temple complex was repaired during the Kengen Era. It is one of the oldest wooden buildings in Japan. It still has some of its original woodwork from its 8th century construction.Pier, Garrett Chatfield. (1914). Temple Treasures of Japan, p. 95. * 1302 (Kengen 1, 6th month): Emperor Go-Nijō made a formal visit to the retirement home of his grandfather, the former Emperor Kameyama.Perkins, George W. (1990). The Clear Mirror: a Chronicle of the Japanese Court during the Kamakura Period, p. 150. Late the same night, Kameyama sent a poem to his grandson in the Imperial palace. Emperor Go-Nijō responded with a poem: ::_English translation_ ::When I raised my eyes ::unable to bear the thought ::of saying goodbye, ::the moon had hidden its light ::in the realm above the clouds. ::_Romaji transliteration_ ::shitawaruru ::nagori ni taezu ::tsuki o mireba ::kumo no ue ni zo ::kage wa narinuru : ::Beyond numbering ::will be the occasions ::when we two will meet ::for you are surely destined ::to live a thousand years. ::kimi wa yoshi ::chitose no yawai ::tameotereba ::aimin koto no ::kazu mo shirarezu : ==Related pages == * Kamakura period ==References== ==Other websites== * National Diet Library, "The Japanese Calendar" Kengen 1st 2nd 1302 1303 Preceded by: Shōan Era or nengō: Kengen Succeeded by: Kagen Category:Japanese eras Category:1302 Category:1303 Category:1300s in Japan
